title: Cursor's Browser Experiment Claims 3M+ Lines of Code
description: Hacker News discussion about Cursor's claim of building a browser with GPT-5.2 that runs uninterrupted for one week with '3M+ lines of code across thousands of files.' Community examines the evidence and implications for AI-assisted development at scale.
author: Hacker News Community

title: Open Responses: Standardizing LLM APIs
description: Simon Willison discusses Open Responses, a new vendor-neutral specification for the JSON API that clients can use to talk to hosted LLMs. Derived from OpenAI's Responses API, with launch partners including OpenRouter, Hugging Face, LM Studio, vLLM, Ollama and Vercel. Willison emphasizes the need for comprehensive conformance test suites for both server implementations and client libraries.
author: Simon Willison

title: The Design & Implementation of Sprites
description: Thomas Ptacek from Fly explains how Sprites work - disposable computers with fast provisioning through warm pools of unused machines in multiple regions. Features custom filesystem on S3-compatible storage with Litestream-replicated local SQLite metadata, providing ~300ms checkpointing and restores.
author: Thomas Ptacek (via Simon Willison)

title: The unhinged world of tech in 2026...
description: Fireship video exploring AI, coding, and programming trends for 2026. The video has 795K views and discusses the evolving landscape of AI-assisted development.
author: Fireship

title: Android Studio Otter 3: LLM Flexibility and Agent Mode
description: Android Developers Blog announces LLM flexibility improvements and Agent Mode enhancements in Android Studio Otter 3 feature drop, enabling new agentic experiences for mobile developers.
author: Android Developers Blog

title: The AI Lab Revolving Door Spins Ever Faster
description: TechCrunch article from January 15, 2026, discussing personnel changes in AI labs, including alignment researcher Jan Leike who left OpenAI in 2024. Examines the rapid movement of talent between AI companies and implications for the industry.
author: TechCrunch

title: AI Models Cracking High-Level Math Problems
description: TechCrunch reports how AI tools have become inescapable in high-level mathematics since GPT-5.2 release, with models now solving complex mathematical problems that were previously challenging for AI systems.
author: TechCrunch

title: Claude Cowork Exfiltrates Files - Security Vulnerability
description: Prompt Armor discovered a vulnerability in Claude Cowork where Anthropic's API domain is on the allowed list, enabling an attack that includes an attacker's own Anthropic API key to upload files to the api.anthropic.com/v1/files endpoint for later retrieval. Demonstrates prompt injection risks in AI agents.
author: Simon Willison

title: Scaling Long-Running Autonomous Coding
description: Hacker News discussion about autonomous coding with predictions that 'by 2029 someone will build a new browser using mainly AI-assisted coding.' Community explores challenges and possibilities of long-running autonomous AI coding agents.
author: Hacker News Community

title: The AI Verification Bottleneck: Developer Toil Isn't Shrinking
description: The New Stack discusses how AI has created new challenges: while code generation is faster, developers spend more time verifying AI-generated code. Explores the 'verification bottleneck' and its impact on developer productivity.
author: The New Stack

title: Anthropic invests $1.5 million in Python Software Foundation
description: Anthropic entered a two-year partnership with PSF to contribute $1.5 million supporting Python ecosystem security, CPython and PyPI improvements, Developer in Residence program, community grants, and core infrastructure. Noted as outstanding news especially following NSF grant withdrawal.
author: Simon Willison

title: Frontend is HARDER for AI than backend (here's how to fix it)
description: Technical video discussing AI coding challenges with frontend versus backend development, offering solutions for improving AI's frontend capabilities.
author: Fireship

title: Generative Coding Named Breakthrough Technology for 2026
description: MIT Technology Review names generative coding as one of 2026's breakthrough technologies, highlighting tools like GitHub Copilot, Cursor, Lovable, and Replit that enable people with little to no coding knowledge to build software.
author: MIT Technology Review

title: Superhuman AI Exfiltrates Emails - Prompt Injection Attack
description: Classic prompt injection attack where untrusted email manipulated Superhuman AI to submit content from dozens of sensitive emails (financial, legal, medical) to attacker's Google Form. Root cause was CSP rule allowing markdown images from docs.google.com. Superhuman treated as high priority incident and issued fix.
author: Simon Willison

title: First impressions of Claude Cowork, Anthropic's general agent
description: Comprehensive review of Claude Cowork, a 'research preview' described as 'Claude Code for the rest of your work', available only to Max subscribers ($100-200/month) as part of updated Claude Desktop macOS application. Detailed analysis of capabilities, limitations, and security considerations for general-purpose AI agents.
author: Simon Willison

title: Linus Torvalds gets the AI coding bug (News)
description: The Changelog news episode covering Linus Torvalds and AI coding tools. Even prominent figures like the Linux creator are reportedly using AI to write code.
author: The Changelog

title: Don't fall into the anti-AI hype
description: Willison discusses anti-AI sentiment in software development community, citing Salvatore Sanfilippo's view that 'Programming changed forever, anyway.' Emphasizes that LLMs will help write better software faster and allow small teams to compete with bigger companies, similar to open source movement in the 90s. Notes heated discussions on HN and Lobste.rs.
author: Simon Willison

title: My answers to questions about porting open source code with LLMs
description: Follow-up to previous post about porting JustHTML from Python to JavaScript using Codex CLI and GPT-5.2. Willison answers his own open questions about ethics and legality of using LLMs for code porting, addressing concerns about licensing, attribution, and the implications for open source development.
author: Simon Willison

title: Linus Torvalds on vibe-coding with AI
description: Linus Torvalds mentions that the python visualizer tool 'has been basically written by vibe-coding' using 'Google Antigravity to do the audio sample visualizer.' Notable admission from the Linux creator about using AI coding tools.
author: Linus Torvalds (via Simon Willison)

title: Realistic software goals for 2026
description: Fireship video discussing practical software development goals for 2026, focusing on realistic expectations and achievable targets.
author: Fireship
